facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 121 of 1955 before the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 22, 1953 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in F.C. Appeal No. 50 of 1947.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated April 15, 1947 of Civil Judge Bahraich in Regular Suit No. 25 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated April 15, 1947, of the Court of the Civil Judge, Bahraich, in Regular Suit No. 25 of 1946.

facts.text: Suit filed on October 18, 1946 as No. 25 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: present suit which was filed on October 18, 1946  No. 25 of 1946 . The appellants case is that the properties in suit are outside the operative provisions of the Act

facts.text: Plaintiffs are members of the Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bharaich.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs who have preferred this appeal are members of the Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bharaich, and, in their suit, they have claimed a declaration that the properties

facts.text: Suit relates to shrine and tomb Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi in village Singha Parasi and appurtenant properties.

anchor.surface_text: The suit from which this appeal arises relates to a shrine and tomb known as Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi situated in the village of Singha Parasi and properties appurtenant to it.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 is Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration, the companysequential injunction and the two other subsidiary reliefs are claimed primarily against respondent 1, the Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh.

facts.text: Respondent 1 issued notification on February 26, 1944 declaring properties as Sunni Waqf under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: it issued the numberification on February 26, 1944, declaring the properties in suit to be a Sunni Waqf under the Act.

facts.text: Appellants claim properties outside operative provisions of U.P. Muslims Waqfs Act XIII of 1936 and not subject to jurisdiction of respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that the properties in suit are outside the operative provisions of the Act and number subject to the jurisdiction of respondent 1,

facts.text: Respondent 1 claims properties form waqf as defined by the Act and subject to its supervision.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the properties in suit did form a waqf as defined by the Act and were companyered by its operative provisions.

facts.text: Trial court held properties not waqf as defined by Act on April 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge held that the properties in suit cannot be held to be waqf as defined by the Act.

facts.text: Trial court held suit within time under s.14 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of limitation the learned judge held that s. 5 2  of the Act applied to the suit but, according to him, though the suit was filed beyond the period of one year prescribed by the said section, it was within time having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Limitation Act.

facts.text: Trial court partly upheld s.53 notice plea, granted declaration and injunction but dismissed other reliefs.

anchor.surface_text: The plea raised by respondent 1 under s. 53 of the Act was partly upheld by the learned trial judge he took the view that the first three relief,-, claimed by the appellants were barred but the fourth was number.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed trial court, held properties constitute waqf under Act, suit barred by s.5(2) limitation and incompetent without s.53 notice, dated April 22, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has reversed the finding of the trial companyrt on the question as to the character of the properties in suit. According to the High Court the said properties companystituted waqf as defined by the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered September 16, 1958 upholding High Court on limitation under s.5(2) and lack of s.53 notice, did not decide waqf status.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by 1289 GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The suit from which this appeal arises relates to a shrine

facts.text: No notice under s.53 of the Act given by appellants before filing suit.

anchor.surface_text: was also in- companypetent in view of the fact that the statutory numberice required by s. 53 of the Act had number been given by the appellants prior to its institution.

facts.text: Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi buried in village Singha Parasi.

anchor.surface_text: On his death his remains were buried in village Singha Parasi by his followers and subsequently a tomb was companystructed.

facts.text: Oudh annexed in 1856, properties confiscated then rights revived.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst the management of the Darga was being thus carried on, Oudh came to be annexed in 1856 and the proclamation issued by Lord Canning companyfiscated all private properties and inams in the said State.

facts.text: Sanad granted to Fakirulla in 1859 or 1860 for rent-free tenure of village Singha Parasi.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that in 1859 or 1860 a Sanad had been granted to Fakirulla who was the head of the khadims in respect of rent-free tenure of the village Singha Parasi.

facts.text: Suit No.1 of 1865 by Inayatulla dismissed on November 11, 1870, properties vested in endowment.

anchor.surface_text: Inayatullas suit was substantially dismissed on November 11, 1870, by the Settlement Officer. It was held that the proprietary rights of the Government in respect of the properties had been alienated for ever in favour of the charity

facts.text: Government took possession of properties under Pensions Act XXIII of 1873.

anchor.surface_text: In the interest of the Darga, Government then decided to take possession of the properties under the provisions of Pensions Act,  XXIII of 1873.

facts.text: Suit by Inayatulla in 1892 dismissed on appeal July 20, 1897.

anchor.surface_text: During this period Inayatulla attempted to assert his rights once more by instituting a suit in the civil companyrt in 1892. ... on appeal the said decree was set aside on July 20, 1897.

facts.text: Suit No.9 of 1902 under s.539 CPC (present s.92) decreed December 3, 1902 declaring properties vest in trustees and scheme framed.

issues.text: Are the properties in suit governed by the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Are the properties in suit governed by the Act ? Is the suit in time ? and Is the suit maintainable without notice as required by s. 53 of the Act ?

Is the suit in time ? and Is the suit maintainable without notice as required by s. 53 of the Act ? The learned trial judge held that the properties in suit cannot be held to be waqf as defined by the Act. In his opinion it was not the village Singha Parasi but its profits free from land revenue that had been granted in trust for the shrine and its khadims

issues.text: Is the suit maintainable without notice as required by s. 53 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: and Is the suit maintainable without notice as required by s. 53 of the Act ? The learned trial judge held that the properties in suit cannot be held to be waqf as defined by the Act. In his opinion it was not the village Singha Parasi but its profits free from land revenue that had been granted in trust for the shrine and its khadims and since the usufruct of the profits was subject to the condition of resumption and since the profits had not been vested in the Almighty, the grant cannot be construed to be a waqf as contemplated by Muhammadan Law. On the question of limitation the learned judge held that s. 5(2)

issues.text: whether the present suit falls within the mischief of s. 5(2) or not

anchor.surface_text: Let us then proceed to consider whether the present suit falls within the mischief of s. 5  2  or number. Section 5  2  provides that The mutawalli of a waqf or any person interested in a waqf or a Central Board may bring a suit in a civil court of competent jurisdiction for a declaration that any transaction held by the Commissioner of waqfs to be a waqf is not a waqf, or any transaction held or assumed by him not to be a waqf is a waqf, or that a waqf held by him to pertain to a particular sect does not belong to that sect, or that any waqf reported by such Commissioner as being subject to the provisions of this Act is exempted under section 2, or that any waqf held by him to be so exempted is subject to this Act.

issues.text: whether the appellants suit is saved by virtue of the provisions of s. 15 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: whether the appellants suit is saved by virtue of the provisions of s. 15 of the Limitation Act. That is the only provision on which reliance was placed before us by Mr. Dar on behalf of the appellants. Section 15. provides for the exclusion of time during which proceedings are suspended and it lays down that in computing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit or application for the execution of a decree, the institution or execution of which has been stayed by an injunction or order, the time of the continuance of the injunction or order, the day on which it was issued or made and the day on which it was withdrawn, shall be excluded .

precedents.cited_proposition: validity of adoption under Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council held that the adoption of Narayan was valid and so the appeal was allowed and Gurunathgoudas suit was dismissed with costs throughout. In the result the injunction granted by the courts below was dissolved on November 4, 1932. Oil  1   1932  35 Bo-. L. R. 200 P. C.

precedents.cited_proposition: issues on validity of adoption decided against Narayan at trial and HC level

anchor.surface_text: Rangnekar J. who delivered the principal judgment exhaustively considered the relevant judicial decisions bearing on the question about the construction of s. 15 and held that the injunction issued against Narayan and Bhimabai in Gurunathgoudas suit did not help to attract s. 15 -to the suit filed by them in 1932 Narayan v. Gurunathgouda  1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: injunction in prior suit does not attract s.15 Limitation Act to subsequent suit

precedents.cited_holding: institution of suit cannot be futile if it prevents limitation running

precedents.cited_proposition: attachment before judgment does not stay institution of suit under s.15 Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: In Sundaramma v. Abdul Khader  2  the Madras High Court, while dealing with s. 15 of the Limitation Act, has held that no equitable grounds for the suspension of the cause of action can be added to the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act.
